questions.text: A 24-day old baby is presented to you with complaints of non-bilious projectile vomiting. Child is not gaining weight and cachexic on examination. Which of the following condition is highly likely?
questions.solution:
• Pyloric stenosis, most commonly seen in age 2weeks to 2 months with male preponderance.
  • Clinical features include Projectile, non-bilious, immediate post-prandial vomiting. Infant is hungry between the feeds.
  • Diagnosis is by ultrasound abdomen that shows thickened pylorus more than 4 mm and pyloric length more than 16mm. Target sign is suggestive of Pyloric stenosis.

  • Management is supportive initially with maintenance of electrolyte balance. Definitive treatment is Pyloromyotomy at the earliest.

Option B: Duodenal atresia has bilious vomiting.

Option C: Hirschsprung disease has a history of delayed passage of stool and gaseous abdominal distention.

Option D: Necrotizing enterocolitis will present earlier in 1-2 weeks with passage of bloody stool, feed intolerance, abdominal distention in background of prematurity or history of formula feeding.

questions.text: A 2-week-old boy is brought to the clinic for persistent vomiting. The neonate is exclusively fed a standard cow milk- based formula. He takes 40ml every 2 hours and vomits a small amount after every feeding, despite burping. The emesis is not bloody, bilious, or projectile. He has 4 yellow, seedy, soft stools per day without blood. He is otherwise healthy. His weight today is greater than his birth weight. Of the following, the MOST likely cause of this neonate's symptoms is
questions.solution:
• The neonate in the vignette has gastroesophageal reflux (GER) caused by overfeeding. In this condition the child is otherwise healthy and grows well with adequate weight gain.
  • Pyloric stenosis and duodenal atresia have persistent vomiting of large amount with failure to thrive.
  • Cow milk protein allergy is with top fed children who develops diarrhea, bloating and vomiting with failure to thrive. It is one of the leading causes of chronic diarrhea.

questions.text: A new born baby presents with abdominal distention, vomiting & absence of bowel movement for 3 days. The barium study is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hirschsprung disease is aganglionosis of bowel. It presents in newborn with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distention and absence of bowel movement on auscultation.
  • The barium enema has segments of dilated bowel followed by transition zone followed by constricted zone of aganglionic bowel. (typical in the above image)

Option A: Volvulus is rotation of bowel on its axis and presents acutely with bilious vomiting and abdominal distention. The barium study shows coffee bean sign.


Option B: Intussusception is bowel in bowel presenting with abdominal pain, vomiting and red-currant jelly stools. It is rare in neonates.

Option C: Celiac disease is not presented in neonates. It is seen after 6 months of age with failure to thrive, diarrhea/constipation and signs of vitamin deficiency due to malabsorption.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male patient presents with lethargy and intermittent fussiness started approximately 10 hours before. The patient has had decreased intake, but normal stool and urine output, no fevers. About one week ago everyone in the home had a viral gastritis that resolved after 48 hours. On your exam, vitals are stable, the patient is sleepy yet arousable on exam, his abdomen is soft and non-tender. Other systems are normal. As you turn to leave exam room the patient started to cry and you noticed that he bent his knees and raised his legs to his abdomen. What is the treatment of choice for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient's probable diagnosis is intussusception. Most commonly occurring at the terminal ilium/colonic junction where the terminal ileum telescopes inside the large intestine.
  • This diagnosis most commonly occurs from the age 3 months to 6 years.
  • The most classic signs/symptoms are intermittent colicky abdominal pain, knee to chest positioning to relieve pain and current jelly stools. Although current jelly stools are a classic sign; it is important to note that this is a very late finding noted by necrosis from the mesenteric lining from the intussuscepted bowel and may not always be seen.

  • Another non-specific finding is a lethargic and intermittently fussy patient as noted by our patient in the vignette. Often there is a history of a recent viral illness as seen in our patient.
  • Air contrast enema is the correct answer choice. With the air contrast enema intussusception can both be diagnosed and treated.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents with abdominal pain. For the past several months, he has had vague complaints of abdominal discomfort. He has felt "bloated" with little appetite. He also states that he is feeling more tired than normal and has been experiencing severe headaches. Although he has had some loose bowel movements, overall, they have been normal, and he that states no blood is apparent in his stool. Prior to this, the patient was healthy. You diagnose the patient with likely celiac disease. What is the first test in work up of the patient?
questions.solution:
• The screening test for celiac disease is IgA TTG levels.
  • However, If the clinical suspicion for celiac disease is strong and screening test is negative, consider performing an intestinal biopsy as most serologic tests have a sensitivity of 80- 90% and a specificity of 90-96%, with some degree of variation. As a result, it is possible that the tests will be falsely negative and should be followed, if suspicion warrants it, by a biopsy.
  • Delaying diagnosis and treatment is not recommended. If the follow-up test is positive, due to the equivocal nature of one positive and one negative test, it is likely that a biopsy would be performed anyway.
  • Ultrasound and MRI of the abdomen may show signs of inflammation but is not as helpful in the definitive diagnosis of celiac disease.

questions.text: A 4-month-old formula-fed infant presents with rectal bleeding without emesis or diarrhea. She was born at term and has not been previously ill. Her weight gain has been appropriate since birth, tracking in the 75th percentile on standardized growth curves. The child is afebrile, with normal vital signs, and appears normal on examination. Of the following which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most common causes of rectal bleeding in the infant periodare a milk protein allergy and an anal fissure. The patient in the case presentation has no physical examination finding, so milk protein allergy is more likely.
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is typically seen in premature infants. NEC can rarely occur in term infants with an associated infection. However, with a normal physical examination and no emesis, this diagnosis is unlikely.
  • Patients with UC do not gain weight well
  • Salmonella infection typically results in other symptoms such as fever and emesis.

questions.text: 2-year-old 10kg child with multiple episodes of diarrhea presents with sunken dry eyes, depressed fontanelles, very slow skin pinch. The amount of fluid to be given in the first 3 hours is
questions.solution:
Hydration status assessment


  • Hence, the child in question is in Severe dehydration.
  • Severe dehydration needs PLAN C for management.

PLAN C

Total fluids to be given- 100ml/kg


  • Hence, for the child in question, first 3 hours need full 100ml/kg fluid, i.e. 100ml x 10kg = 1000ml

questions.text: An 8-month-old child has profuse diarrhea since last 3 days. The stool routine shows absence of blood and stool culture shows no growth. There is no fever and no dehydration. Child is growing fine otherwise. The perianal area shows skin excoriation. What is likely cause of this diarrheal illness?
questions.solution:
• The history is very much suggestive of post viral lactose malabsorption. After the viral enteritis, the mucosal brush border cells are lost and these causes lactose malabsorption.
  • Also, perianal excoriation is favorable to diagnosis of lactose intolerance.
  • Other bacterial enteritis might show growth in culture or may have changes in stool routine like pus cells, occult blood. Though, they cannot be ruled out completely, likelihood of lactose malabsorption is more than bacterial.
  • Celiac disease is a cause of chronic diarrhea and failure to thrive.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child has acute gastroenteritis and is in some dehydration. What will be the amount of ORS to be given to the child per loose stool, over and above the correction fluid?
questions.solution:
PLAN B- For Some dehydration

ORS to be given

  • Correction volume- 75ml/kg over 4 hours + 10-20ml/kg/loose stool
  • Orally if child accepts well
  • Feeding tube inserted if oral intake insufficient

questions.text: A 9-week-old infant is brought to you for persistent vomiting and is found to have the following radiological findings. What is the most likely metabolic disturbance in this infant?
questions.solution:
• The barium swallow is suggestive for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
  • In pyloric stenosis to compensate for water loss, there is renal compensation by reabsorbing Na in exchange for K, leading to hypokalemia.
  • Also, the child would be losing HCl via vomiting, hence the hypochloremiaand alkalosis.

questions.text: While promoting oral fluids in a child with active diarrhea, which of the following fluids must be avoided completely?
questions.solution:
• While treating the child with dehydration, we must promote intake of clear liquids like water, ORS, Lemonade, coconut water
  • We must continue breastfeeding, formula feeds.
  • We must completely avoid fruit juices and carbonated drinks.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is most suggestive of a diagnosis of IgE-mediated cow's milk protein allergy rather than non-IgE mediated?
questions.solution:
• IgE mediated cow's milk protein allergies have a rapid onset of up to 2 hours after ingestion, whereas non-IgE mediated are more delay and may not present until up to a week after ingestion.
  • Both IgE and non-IgE mediated cow's milk protein allergy can cause pruritis, erythema, and lower respiratory tract infections including wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath.
  • Loose stools is more characteristic of non-IgE mediated allergies.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the GP by his mother with a 4-month history of weight loss, abdominal cramping and bloating. The GP suspects coeliac disease and orders an anti-TTG. Which of the following tests does the GP need to order in addition to this to identify a false negative result?
questions.solution:
• In a child with low total IgA levels, the anti-TTG levels may be low enough to given false negative results.
  • In these patients, more definitive tests like Anti-EMA and HLA may be done. Some may need duodenal biopsy.

questions.text: A 3-day old neonate comes to you with not passed stool since birth. You suspect Hirschsprung disease. What is the gold standard diagnosis for the same?
questions.solution:
• Rectal suction biopsyis the gold standard for diagnosing Hirschsprung disease. The biopsy material should contain an adequate amount of submucosa to evaluate for the presence of ganglion cells.
  • Patients with aganglionosis demonstrate a large number of hypertrophied nerve bundles that stain positively for acetylcholinesterase with an absence of ganglion cells.

  • All other tests mentioned are helpful but not diagnostic.

choices.text: Ensure infant is not over fed

questions.text: According to NICE guidelines, what is the first line of management for a formula fed child with significant gastric reflux?
questions.solution:
• If breastfedwith frequent regurgitation causing marked distress, use an alginate mixed with water immediately after feeds.
  • If formula-fedwith frequent regurgitation causing marked distress, use a step-wise approach:

  • For either group if there is no improvement with alginate therapy after a 2 week trial then start proton pump inhibitor or histamine antagonist(eg. Omeprazole or ranitidine)

Reference: NICE guidelines for GORD

questions.text: Which of the following is not a known risk factor for intussusception?
questions.solution:
Factors increasing the risk of Intussusception

  • Meckel diverticulum (most common)
  • Polyps
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  • Lymphoma and other tumors
  • Post-operative

questions.text: What is the dose of Zinc to be given to a 10-month-old child with acute diarrhea?
questions.solution:
• All children ageing more than 6 months suffering from acute diarrheal illness must receive zinc at 20mg/day for 10-14 days.
  • It helps for regeneration of damaged mucosa and reduces diarrhea related mortality.

Reference: IMNCI guidelines, management of acute gastroenteritis

choices.text: Failure of gut to return to the body cavity from its physiological herniation

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the condition given in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Exomphalos(omphalocele) is herniation of abdominal viscera through an enlarged umbilical ring.
  • The viscera, which may include liver, small and large intestines, stomach, spleen, or bladder, are covered by amnion.

  • The origin of omphalocele is a failure of the bowel to return to the body cavity from its physiological herniation during the 6th to 10th weeks.
  • Duplication of intestinal loops commonly seen in jejunum.
  • Abnormal rotation causes malrotation of gut
  • Reverse rotation can cause volvulus or intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: Parents of a 3-month-old infant comes to you with complaint of blood in stool over last 15 days. He has been treated with oral antibiotic and probiotic but no improvement. The child is otherwise healthy, feeds and sleeps well. Which of the following condition is not considered in the differential diagnosis of the child?
questions.solution:
• An infant with painless lower GI bleedhas 3 differentials-
    • Meckle's diverticula
    • Lymphonodular hyperplasia
    • Intestinal duplication.
  • Other causes of lower GI bleed in infants like volvulus, intussusception, colitis, anal fissure, infantile colitis presents with other associated complaints and they are painful.

questions.text: What is the normal color of stool in the newborn after first week of life?
questions.solution:
• Meconium (first stool) is passed within 24 hours.
  • After that meconium stools (black tarry)can be passed upto 3 days.
  • On 4th-5th days transitional stools (greenish) are passed.
  • After 5 days regular milk stools (golden yellow) are passed.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with severe acute liver failure is being cared for in the intensive care unit. Which of the following laboratory findings best reflects worsening liver function in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Rising total bilirubin in the setting of acute liver failure with loss of hepatic function is an ominous sign that is likely multifactorial in nature.
  • This may be due to reduced hepatic uptake, decreased bile conjugation, and/or decreased biliary excretion as hepatocyte death progresses.
  • Serum aminotransferase elevation is usually secondary to hepatocellular injury due to inflammation, toxin, or passive congestion, although there are extrahepatic causes of elevated transaminases as well. Aminotransferases levels may remain stable or trend downward even as bilirubin rises as liver failure and hepatocellular dealt progress.So, up trending AST/ALT do not necessarily reflect loss of hepatic function.
  • Factor VIIis a clotting protein synthesized in the liver that, when levels decline to less than 12% of normal, may predict fulminant hepatic failure.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy seen in your clinic has a history of Wilson disease. Which of the following tissues may accumulate excessive copper if the disease is left inadequately treated?
questions.solution:
• Wilson disease is a metal metabolism disorder characterized by excessive copper deposition in the liver, brain, kidneys, and eyes.

  • Patients with Wilson diseasemay suffer from arthralgias and osteoarthritis but do not typically develop copper deposition in the bones, pancreas, ovaries, or salivary glands.

questions.text: A 2-month-old, is evaluated for jaundice and failure to thrive. He undergoes a percutaneous liver biopsy that shows a paucity of bile ducts. Which of the following would not be considered an appropriate investigation in the course of disease evaluation?
questions.solution:
• The finding of bile duct paucity on liver biopsy, in the setting of poor growth, is characteristic of Alagille syndrome, a multisystem, inherited disorder with highly variable clinical features. A paucity of bile ducts is considered the most important and constant feature of this disease.
  • Features are:
    • Cholestasis
    • Abnormal faces like broad forehead, wide eyes, long nose, underdeveloped jaw
    • Ocular abnormalities like posterior embryotoxon
    • Cardiovascular abnormalities
    • Vertebral defects like butterfly vertebrae
    • Tubulointerstitial nephropathy
  • Evaluation includes
    • Liver biopsy
    • Echocardiogram for cardiac defects
    • AP and lateral chest radiographs for butterfly vertebrae
    • Ophthalmologic examination for anterior chamber involvement
    • Renal ultrasound and renal function testing to identify renal complications
  • A skin biopsy is unlikely to be useful in evaluating the cause of this patient's liver disease.

choices.text: Total and free carnitine and acylcarnitine

questions.text: A previously healthy 9-year-Old male presents to the ER with asymptomatic jaundice and is found to have a total bilirubin of 11 mg/dL with a direct component of 8.5 mg/dL. Which of the following tests is the most useful indicator of hepatic synthetic function?
questions.solution: • The most useful indicator of this child's hepatic synthetic functionis the PT, which will be prolonged if the liver fails to synthesize clotting factors.

choices.text: Combination therapy with Zinc and D-penicillamine
Combination therapy with Zinc and Ammonium tetrathiomolybdate

questions.text: A 12-year-old child has hepatic illness. On ophthalmological examination following finding is seen. He also has tendency to forget common things of daily activities. Which of the following is not the treatment option for the child?
questions.solution:
• The image is suggestive of Keyser Fleischer ring. Also, the child has hepatic illness and dementia. These findings are suggestive of Wilson disease.

Mnemonic for clinical features of Wilson disease: ABCD

  1. Asterixis, Anemia (Coombs negative)
  2. Basal ganglia lesion- Parkinson features in young
  3. Copper deposition, Cirrhosis, Corneal deposits (KF ring), Choreoathetosis
  4. Dementia, Dystonia, Depression

Treatment options:

  • Chelation therapy
    • D-penicillamine- never combined with Zinc
    • Trientine
    • Ammonium Tetrathiomolybdate- most useful in CNS involvement
  • Zinc
    • reduces GI absorption of copper, as an adjuvant therapy
    • useful in CNS disease
  • Liver transplant- definitive therapy in fulminant hepatic failure or cirrhosis.
